{{Further|Subprime crisis impact timeline}} {{Subprime mortgage crisis sidebar}}
This article gives the '''timeline of the [[Great Recession]]''', which hit many developed economies in the wake of the [[financial crisis of 2007-2008]].
'''Note:''' The date indicated is that of the official announcement by the department or the public agency in charge of the measurement of the economic activity of the country. Thus, because of possible lags in the collection of statistics, it is possible that the chronological order of reports may not correspond to the actual order of events in recession.
==Definition of recession== A [[recession]] is a period of two quarters of negative GDP growth. The countries listed are those that officially announced that they were in recession.
It is worth noting that some developed countries such as [[South Korea]] and [[Australia]] did not enter recession (indeed Australia contracted for the last quarter of 2008 only to grow 1% for the first half of 2009). [[Poland]], then considered to be an [[Emerging markets|emerging market]] country, also avoided the recession as a result of their strong domestic market, low private debt and flexible currency.<ref>{{cite news|title=How Poland became only EU nation to avoid recession|date=29 Jun 2010|first1=Fred|last1=Pleitgen|first2=Catriona|last2=Davies |work=CNN|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-29/world/poland.economy.recession_1_poland-transition-economies-eastern-europe|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120701160136/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-06-29/world/poland.economy.recession_1_poland-transition-economies-eastern-europe|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 July 2012|accessdate=23 May 2011}} </ref>
==Timeline overview== {{Timeline of the Great Recession}}
==2008==
===July=== *July 1, 2008: {{flagicon|Denmark}} '''[[Economy of Denmark|Denmark]]''' Denmark becomes the first European economy to confirm it is in recession since the global credit crunch began. Its GDP shrinks 0.6% in the first quarter after a 0.2% contraction in the fourth quarter of 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Denmark enters recession|date=1 Jul 2008|first=Tasneem|last=Brogger|work=Bloomberg|publisher=Independent|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/european/denmark-enters-recession-1425013.html|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref>
===August=== *August 13, 2008: {{flagicon|Estonia}} '''[[Economy of Estonia|Estonia]]''' The Baltic state slides into recession with a 0.9% fall in second-quarter GDP after a drop of 0.5% in the first quarter. It falls deeper into recession in the third quarter when the economy contracted 3.3%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Recession arrives in Estonia|date=13 Aug 2008|first=Mike|last=Collier|work=The Baltic Times|location=Tallinn|url=http://www.baltictimes.com/news/articles/21072|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
===September=== *September 8, 2008: {{flagicon|Latvia}} '''[[Economy of Latvia|Latvia]]''' Latvia joins its northern neighbor Estonia in recession as GDP falls 0.2% in the second quarter from the first quarter, when it fell 0.3%. Property markets and construction have suffered in both Baltic states.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hard crash for Latvia’s housing market |date=26 Jan 2009 |url=http://www.globalpropertyguide.com/Europe/Latvia/Price-History |work=Global Property Guide |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415180102/http://globalpropertyguide.com/Europe/Latvia/Price-History |archivedate=April 15, 2009 }}</ref>
*September 25, 2008: {{flagicon|Ireland}} '''[[Economy of the Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]''' The "[[Celtic Tiger]]" slides into recession for the first time in over two decades, recording a 0.5% fall in second quarter GDP, following a 0.3% decline in the first quarter. Its last recession in 1983 saw thousands of people leave Ireland to seek work overseas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ireland falls into recession|date=25 Sep 2008|first=Julia|last=Kollewe|work=Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/sep/25/recession.ireland|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
===October=== *October 10, 2008: {{flagicon|Singapore}} '''[[Economy of Singapore|Singapore]]''' First Asian country to slip into a recession since the credit crisis began. Singapore's export-dependent economy shrank an annualized 6.3% in the third quarter after a revised 5.7% contraction in the second quarter; its first recession since 2002.<ref>{{cite news|title=Singapore enters recession|first=Olivia|last=Boyd|date=10 October 2008|work=Building|url=http://m.building.co.uk/news/singapore-enters-recession/3124810.article|accessdate=1 Jun 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820095041/http://m.building.co.uk/news/singapore-enters-recession/3124810.article|archive-date=2011-08-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Growth has faltered in Singapore as a result of less demand for exports, a reduction in tourism, and the end of the real-estate boom.<ref name="Adam">{{cite news|title=Singapore, in Recession, Ends Currency Gain Policy (Update2)|first=Shamim|last=Adam|date=9 Oct 2008|work=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?sid=aCfJDzdRR1ls&pid=newsarchive|accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> Singapore's manufacturing sector had declined 4.9% in the previous quarter.<ref name="Adam"/>
*October 24, 2008: {{flagicon|Iceland}} '''[[Economy of Iceland|Iceland]]''' Iceland receives a £1.3 billion (US$2.06 billion, €1.63 billion) bailout package from the [[International Monetary Fund]] as the first European country to require an emergency loan with the aim of stabilising the collapsed currency and strengthening the tax system as well as the nationalised banks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iceland to get £1.3bn IMF loan|date=24 Oct 2008|first=Rowena|last=Mason|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/recession/3254993/Iceland-to-get-1.3bn-IMF-loan.html|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
*October 27, 2008: {{flagicon|Australia}} '''[[Economy of Australia|Australia]]''' The banking group [[BNP Paribas]] states that Australia is in a risky position with regards to the global financial crisis as foreign liabilities accounted for 60% of the nation's GDP.<ref>{{cite news|title=Yen surge stokes stability fears as 'Aussie' slides|date=27 Oct 2008|first=Ambrose|last=Evans-Pritchard|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/ambroseevans_pritchard/3270014/Yen-surge-stokes-stability-fears-as-Aussie-slides.html|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*October 28, 2008 {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''[[Economy of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]]''' 500,000 mortgage holders are left in [[negative equity]] after house prices dropped 15% since the previous summer, with another 700,000 mortgage holders facing the same risk if prices continue to fall.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bank of England: 1.2million face negative equity as property slumps|date=28 Oct 2008|first=Edmund|last=Conway|work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/3270886/Bank-of-England-1.2million-face-negative-equity-as-property-slumps.html|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
===November=== *November 13, 2008: {{flagicon|Germany}} '''[[Economy of Germany|Germany]]''' Europe's largest economy contracted by 0.5% in the third quarter after GDP fell 0.4% in the second quarter, putting it in recession for the first time in five years.<ref>{{cite news|title=German economy officially in recession |date=13 Nov 2008 |work=AFP |publisher=France 24 |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20081113-german-economy-officially-recession-financial-crisis-europe |accessdate=31 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522081838/http://www.france24.com/en/20081113-german-economy-officially-recession-financial-crisis-europe |archivedate=22 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>
*November 13, 2008: {{flagicon|Indonesia}} '''[[Economy of Indonesia|Indonesia]]''', {{flagicon|Malaysia}} '''[[Economy of Malaysia|Malaysia]]''', {{flagicon|Thailand}} '''[[Economy of Thailand|Thailand]]''', {{flagicon|Philippines}} '''[[Economy of the Philippines|The Philippines]]''' Equity research by [[Deutsche Bank]] states that Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines should not experience a recession, despite potential harm to economic growth from falling commodity prices and possible weaker exports.<ref>{{cite news|title=No recession in RP—Deutsche Bank, RP gov’t |date=13 Nov 2008 |first=Carmie |last=Carpio |work=Asian Journal |url=http://www.asianjournal.com/dateline-philippines/headlines/580-no-recession-in-rpdeutsche-bank-rp-govt.html |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909150355/http://www.asianjournal.com/dateline-philippines/headlines/580-no-recession-in-rpdeutsche-bank-rp-govt.html |archivedate=9 September 2011 |df= }}</ref>
*November 14, 2008: {{flagicon|Italy}} '''[[Economy of Italy|Italy]]''' Italy plunges into recession, its first since the start of 2005, after GDP contracts a steeper-than-expected 0.5% in the third quarter. Second quarter GDP dropped 0.3%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Istat, pil italiano a -0,9%: è recessione tecnica Ma le Borse Ue reagiscono: piazza Affari +1,6%|date=14 Nov 2008|language=Italian|work=Il Giornale|location=Milan|url=http://www.ilgiornale.it/economia/istat_pil_italiano_-09_e_recessione_tecnica_ma_borse_ue_reagiscono_piazza_affari_16/14-11-2008/articolo-id=306101|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*November 14, 2008: {{flagicon|Hong Kong}} '''[[Economy of Hong Kong|Hong Kong]]''' Hong Kong becomes the second Asian economy to tip into recession, its exports hit by weakening global demand. Third-quarter GDP drops a seasonally adjusted 0.5% after a 1.4% fall in the previous quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong slides into recession|date=14 Nov 2008|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7729652.stm|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
*November 14, 2008: {{flagicon|European Union}} '''[[Eurozone]]''' Taken as a whole the Eurozone officially slips under, pushed down by recessions in Germany and Italy for its first recession since its creation in 1999.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eurozone officially in recession|work=BBC News|date=14 Nov 2008 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7729018.stm|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Euro zone recession confirmed|date=4 December 2008|first=Jan|last=Strupczewski|work=Reuters|location=Brussels |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE4B32JK20081204|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> These 15 countries are: [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Cyprus]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Greece]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Malta]], [[Netherlands]], [[Portugal]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]]. On January 1, 2009, [[Slovakia]] adopted the euro, and so is now part of the Eurozone. Though the Eurozone suffers from recession as a whole, Belgium, France, Greece, and Slovakia still have better growth.
*November 17, 2008: {{flagicon|Japan}} '''[[Economy of Japan|Japan]]''' The world's second-biggest economy slides into recession, its first in seven years. Its GDP contracts 0.1% in the July–September quarter, as the financial crisis curbs demand for its exports. It shrank 0.9% in the previous quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan joins growing list of countries to fall into recession|date=17 Nov 2008|first=Harry|last=Wallop|work=Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/3472608/Japan-joins-growing-list-of-countries-to-fall-into-recession.html|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
*November 23, 2008: {{flagicon|Hawaii}} '''[[Economy of Hawaii|Hawaii]]''' Economists at the [[University of Hawaii]] reported that the state entered the recession in the previous quarter based on the drop in tourist figures and growing unemployment, with 8,800 jobs expected to be cut in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=UH forecast sees ‘deep’ Hawaii recession through ’09|date=23 Nov 2008|first=Janis L.|last=Magin|work=Pacific Business News |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/stories/2008/11/24/story2.html|accessdate=5 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*November 28, 2008: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''[[Economy of Canada|Canada]]''' In 2008, Canada had positive GDP growth in Q2 and Q3 but GDP fell by a sharp 3.4% annualized in Q4. Growth is widely expected to remain in recession territory going into 2009. Canada is the only OECD country out of the recession at this time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Recession in Canada now official, OECD says|date=28 Nov 2008|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=Daily Commercial News|location=Ottawa|url=http://dcnonl.com/article/id31550|accessdate=31 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728132505/http://dcnonl.com/article/id31550|archive-date=2011-07-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
*November 28, 2008: {{flagicon|Sweden}} '''[[Economy of Sweden|Sweden]]''' Sweden technically enters the recession after experiencing contraction of 0.1% in the second and third quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=La Suède entre à son tour en récession|language=French|date=28 Nov 2008|work=La Tribune |url=http://www.latribune.fr/actualites/economie/international/20081128trib000315353/la-suede-entre-a-son-tour-en-recession.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===December=== *December 1, 2008: {{flagicon|United States}} '''[[Economy of the United States of America|United States]]''' The US economy has been in recession since December 2007, the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] announced in December 2008. The bureau is a private research institute widely regarded as the official arbiter of US economic cycles. It said a 73-month economic expansion had come to an end.<ref>{{cite news|title=NBER: U.S. In Recession That Began Last December|date=1 Dec 2008|work=Washington Post|first=Neil|last=Irwin|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/01/AR2008120101365.html|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> The Bureau stated that the deteriorating labour market throughout 2008 provided reason to state the commencement of the recession as December 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=It's official: Recession since Dec. '07|date=1 Dec 2008|first=Chris|last=Isidore|work=CNN Money|location=New York|url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/12/01/news/economy/recession/index.htm?postversion=2008120112|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*December 12, 2008: {{flagicon|Russia}} '''[[Economy of Russia|Russia]]''' [[Andrei Klepach]], a deputy economics minister of Russia, states that Russia has entered the recession, with two quarters of contraction expected, meaning Russia will fall short of reaching the 6.8% growth forecast for 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia has entered recession: minister|date=12 Dec 2008|work=Live Mint|location=Moscow|url=http://www.livemint.com/2008/12/12165832/Russia-has-entered-recession.html|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
==2009==
===January=== *January 13, 2009: {{flagicon|South Korea}} '''[[Economy of South Korea|South Korea]]''', {{flagicon|Republic of China}} '''[[Economy of Taiwan|Taiwan]]''', {{flagicon|Japan}} '''Japan''', {{flagicon|United States}} '''United States''' Global shipping experiences a drop in trade, as exports from South Korea dropping an annualised 30%, with Taiwan and Japan experiencing a 42% and 27% drop respectively. Outgoing traffic in the United States dropped 18% from [[Port of Long Beach|Long Beach]] and [[Port of Los Angeles|Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Shipping rates hit zero as trade sinks|date=13 Jan 2009|first=Ambrose|last=Evans-Pritchard|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/4229198/Shipping-rates-hit-zero-as-trade-sinks.html|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*January 23, 2009: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The UK officially enters the recession as GDP fell by 1.5% in the last quarter of 2008 following a 0.6% drop in the third quarter,<ref>{{cite news|title=UK recession: It's now official|date=23 Jan 2009|first=Angela |last=Monaghan|work=The Telegraph|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8015704.stm|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref> with unemployment growing by 131,000 to 1.92 million (6.1%) in the three months leading to November 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Unemployment leaps closer to 2 million|date=21 Jan 2009|first1=Ashley|last1=Seager|first2=Kathryn|last2=Hopkins|work=Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jan/21/unemployment-jobs-recession|accessdate=26 Jun 2011}}</ref> The British economy only grew 0.7% in 2008, the weakest growth since 1992.<ref>{{cite news|title=Recession Britain: It's official|date=23 Jan 2009|first=Julia |last=Kollewe|work=Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jan/23/recession-uk-unemployment|accessdate=26 Jun 201}}</ref>
===February=== *February 13, 2009: {{flagicon|Netherlands}} '''[[Economy of the Netherlands|Netherlands]]''' The Dutch Statistics agency confirms the Netherlands are in recession since April 2008; with updated figures showing minor economic reductions in the 2nd and 3rd quarters of 2008, and a 0.9% reduction in the 4th quarter <ref>{{cite news|title=Nederland sinds april in recessie|language=Dutch|date=13 Feb 2009|work=Nu.nl|location=The Hague|url=http://www.nu.nl/economie/1916750/nederland-sinds-april-in-recessie.html|accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
*February 18, 2009: {{flagicon|Republic of China}} '''Taiwan''' The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics announced that its economy had contracted an unprecedented 8.36% in the fourth quarter of 2008; and also recorded 2 consecutive quarters of economic contraction, thus placing the country in a technical recession.<ref>{{cite news|title=Taiwan in recession as economy contracts record 8.36 pct|date=18 Feb 2009|work=AFP|publisher=Google|location=Taipei |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hX_yLdUnz5f88yZ0hRevt3LQyP-w|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124224105/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hX_yLdUnz5f88yZ0hRevt3LQyP-w|dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 January 2013|accessdate=15 May 2011}} </ref>
*February 27, 2009: {{flagicon|Finland}} '''[[Economy of Finland|Finland]]''' [[Statistics Finland]] informs that Finland's gross domestic product diminished by 1.3% in the last quarter of 2008 from the previous quarter. The growth slowed down already in early 2008 and in the third quarter output diminished by 0.3% from the previous quarter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gross domestic product in decline, Finland is in recession|date=27 Feb 2009|publisher=Statistics Finland|url=http://www.stat.fi/ajk/tiedotteet/2009/tiedote_003_2009-02-27_en.html|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
===March=== *March 4, 2009: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' [[U.S. Steel]] announced the closure of the [[Stelco Lake Erie Works]] in [[Nanticoke, Ontario|Nanticoke]], [[Ontario]] due to the increasingly worse effects of the global economic slowdown.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stelco's Hamilton and Lake Erie plants idled |date=4 Mar 2009 |first=Naomi |last=Powell |work=The Toronto Star |location=Hamilton |url=https://www.thestar.com/business/article/596186--stelco-s-hamilton-and-lake-erie-plants-idled |accessdate=25 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616151559/http://www.thestar.com/business/article/596186--stelco-s-hamilton-and-lake-erie-plants-idled |archivedate=June 16, 2010 }}</ref> While it may have decreased the local pollution levels, it also has affected 12000 jobs both at the Lake Erie Works and in the Haldimand-Norfolk area.
*March 4, 2009: {{flagicon|Malaysia}} '''Malaysia''' Malaysia has a 50% chance of slipping into the recession as growth is expected to reach just 0.5% for the year, said the executive director [[Datuk Mohamed Ariff Abdul Kareem]] of the [[Malaysian Institute of Economic Research]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysia may face full-blown recession|date=4 Mar 2009|first=K.C|last=Law|work=The Star|location=Kuala Lumpur|url=http://biz.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?sec=business&file=/2009/3/4/business/3397864|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
===May=== *May 15, 2009: {{flagicon|France}} '''[[Economy of France|France]]''', {{flagicon|Austria}} '''[[Economy of Austria|Austria]]''', {{flagicon|Belgium}} '''[[Economy of Belgium|Belgium]]''', {{flagicon|Romania}} '''[[Economy of Romania|Romania]]''', {{flagicon|Lithuania}} '''[[Economy of Lithuania|Lithuania]]''', {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} '''[[Economy of Luxembourg|Luxembourg]]''', {{flagicon|Portugal}} '''[[Economy of Portugal|Portugal]]''', {{flagicon|Hungary}} '''[[Economy of Hungary|Hungary]]''' The [[INSEE|French Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies]] announced that French gross domestic product shrank 1.2% in the first quarter of 2009 after falling by 1.5% in the final quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=France officially hit by recession |date=15 May 2009 |work=AFP |publisher=France 24 |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20090515-france-officially-hit-recession-gdp-negative-growth-economic-crisis |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518023638/http://www.france24.com/en/20090515-france-officially-hit-recession-gdp-negative-growth-economic-crisis |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009 |df= }} </ref> The French economy had avoided narrowly a recession in 2008. The GDP is expected to keep shrinking in 2009. [[Eurostat]] also reported at this time that [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], and [[Romania]] had all entered recession in the first quarter of 2009, with two consecutive quarters of shrinking GDP, while [[Lithuania]], [[Luxembourg]], and [[Portugal]] had already done so in the last quarter of 2008 and [[Hungary]] in the quarter before that.<ref>{{cite web|title=Euro area and EU27 GDP down by 2.5% |date=15 May 2009 |publisher=Eurostat |url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-15052009-BP/EN/2-15052009-BP-EN.PDF |accessdate=16 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611205041/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-15052009-BP/EN/2-15052009-BP-EN.PDF |archivedate=11 June 2009 |df= }}</ref>
*May 19, 2009: {{flagicon|Norway}} '''[[Economy of Norway|Norway]]''' Norway's mainland GDP, which excludes the oil and gas sectors and the shipping industry, shrank 1.0% in the three months to March after a 0.8% decline in the final quarter of 2008, with recession counted as two consecutive quarterly figures showing a contraction. Mainland GDP is considered a better indicator of the Scandinavian country's economic health, since the oil and gas sector represents 25% of its economic growth but employs only about one% of its working-age population. Still, Norway's total GDP, which includes the oil, gas and shipping sectors, shrank 0.4% in the first quarter of 2009 after 0.8% growth in the fourth quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Despite energy reserves, Norway slips into recession|date=19 May 2009|first=Matthew|last=Saltmarsh|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/business/global/20kroner.html|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
*May 20, 2009: {{flagicon|Mexico}} '''[[Economy of Mexico|Mexico]]''' Mexico becomes the first Latin American country to officially enter recession, having its GDP shrink 8.22% in the first quarter of 2009, after falling 1.6% in the final quarter of 2008 and Swine flu concerns. To this date, it is estimated that the Mexican domestic product will shrink 5.5% in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=México entró en recesión|language=Spanish|date=21 May 2009|work=AFP|publisher=La Prensa Gráfica|location=Mexico City|url=http://www.laprensagrafica.com/economia/internacional/34375-mexico-entro-en-recesion.html|accessdate=9 Jun 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522224336/http://www.laprensagrafica.com/economia/internacional/34375-mexico-entro-en-recesion.html|archive-date=2009-05-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Ministry of Finances Agustin Carstens declared the country in recession on May 7, 2009, based on estimates, which were confirmed when the actual, real data was released on May 20 by [[INEGI]].
*May 25, 2009: {{flagicon|Thailand}} '''Thailand''' Thailand’s economy shrank more than expected in the first quarter, contracting the most in a decade, plunging the nation into recession. GDP shrank 7.1% in the last quarter of 2008, followed by another shrinking of 4.2% in the first quarter of 2009. According to the Singapore branch of [[Macquarie Group]], the Thai economy is expected to recover in the fourth quarter of 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thai Economy Contracts More Than Forecast, Enters Recession|date=25 May 2009|first=Suttinee|last=Yuvejwattana|work=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aiIg0Ah7usTY|accessdate=10 Jun 2009}}</ref>
*May 27, 2009: {{flagicon|South Africa}} '''[[Economy of South Africa|South Africa]]''' South Africa entered recession as the global crisis pounded demand for its main exports; GDP shrank 6.4% in the first quarter of 2009 after falling 1.8% in the last quarter of 2008. This is the first recession for South Africa in 17 years. According to forecasts, the South African domestic product is likely to shrink between 1% and 1.5% in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=South Africa enters recession, GDP falls 6.4%|date=27 May 2009|first=Robb M.|last=Stewart|work=The Wall Street Journal|location=Johannesburg |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124336591959555389|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===June=== *June 2, 2009: {{flagicon|Switzerland}} '''[[Economy of Switzerland|Switzerland]]''' Switzerland officially entered a recession in the first quarter of 2009 when its economy shrank by 0.8%, after contracting 0.3% in the last quarter of 2008. The contraction was caused mainly by weakness in exports, which fell 5.4% in the quarter. Meanwhile, the Swiss watch industry had been reporting double-digit declines in watch exports for the past four months.<ref>{{cite news|title=Switzerland enters recession in first quarter|date=2 Jun 2009|work=RTÉ Business|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0602/switzerland-business.html|accessdate=10 Jun 2009}}</ref>
*June 5, 2009: {{flagicon|Chile}} '''[[Economy of Chile|Chile]]''' First South American country to enter the recession.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chile entró oficialmente en recesión|date=5 Jun 2009|language=Spanish|work=DPA|publisher=La Nación|location=Santiago|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1136079&high=Chile|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
*June 9, 2009: {{flagicon|Brazil}} '''[[Economy of Brazil|Brazil]]''' Brazil slipped into a recession in the first quarter of 2009. <ref>{{cite news|title=Brazil's economy enters recession|date=9 Jun 2009|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8091632.stm |accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*June 11, 2009: {{flagicon|Bulgaria}} '''[[Economy of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]]''' Bulgarian authorities declare the country is officially in recession after dropping 1.6% in the last quarter of 2008, followed by a 5% drop in the first quarter of 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bulgaria's Economy Shrinks by 5%|date=11 Jun 2009|first=Stefan|last=Kioutchukov|work=Standart |url=http://paper.standartnews.com/en/article.php?d=2009-06-11&article=27772|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> Unemployment is rising rapidly and by September 500,000 people are expected to lose their jobs. Exports are down 50%. For the first three months of 2009 GDP has shrunk by 2%. Households and small businesses are heavily in debt.
*June 25, 2009: {{flagicon|Colombia}} '''[[Economy of Colombia|Colombia]]''' Colombia enters into recession after witnessing 0.7% contraction in the last quarter of 2008 and 0.6% in the following quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colombia officially in recession|date=25 Jun 2009|first=Adriaan|last=Alsema|work=Colombia Reports |url=http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/economy/4709-colombia-officially-in-recession.html|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref>
*June 30, 2009: {{flagicon|Turkey}} '''[[Economy of Turkey|Turkey]]''' Turkey recorded its fastest contraction of 13.8% in the first quarter of 2009 compared to 2008, leading the country into recession after a contraction of 6.2% in the last quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Turkish GDP falls 13.8%, economy enters recession|date=30 Jun 2009|work=Hurriyet Daily News|location=Istanbul|url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=11971517|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> This is Turkey's biggest economic slump since 1945.<ref>{{cite news|title=Turkey in biggest slump since 1945|date=1 Jul 2009|work=Hurriyet Daily News|location=Istanbul |url=http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=11976384|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref>
===July=== *July 14, 2009: {{flagicon|Singapore}} '''Singapore''' Singapore experienced a seasonally adjusted and annualised growth of 20.4% in the second quarter as a result of increased pharmaceuticals production and construction, bringing the country out of the recession.<ref>{{cite news|title=Drugs drag Singapore out of recession|date=14 Jul 2009|first1=Nopporn|last1=Wong-Anan|first2=Kevin|last2=Lim|first3=Saeed|last3=Azar|work=Reuters|location=Singapore |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2009/07/14/idINIndia-41015420090714|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref>
*July 23, 2009: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' On 23 July, the [[Bank of Canada]] made comments that most media interpreted as an effective statement predicting with strong certainty that the recession is over with expected growth in GDP beginning the current quarter.<ref name=endcanrec>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/tsx-surges-as-bnk-of-canada-declares-end-to-recession/article1228170/ Recession in Canada is Over] {{Dead link |date=December 2016}}</ref> The Bank of Canada announced the end of the recession even though it was nascent and still dependent on government stimulus money.<ref name=endcanrec/>
===August=== *August 13, 2009: {{flagicon|France}} '''France''', {{flagicon|Germany}} '''Germany''' The French and German GDP both grew 0.3% in the second quarter of 2009; analysts had not anticipated such a quick recovery.<ref>{{cite news|title=France and Germany exit recession|date=13 Aug 2009|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8198766.stm|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*August 14, 2009: {{flagicon|Hong Kong}} '''Hong Kong''' After shrinking 4.3% during January–March, Hong Kong's GDP grew 3.3% between April and June, improving its GDP forecasts, which went from negative growth between 5.5 and 6.5% to negative growth between 4.5 and 5.5%. Still, comparing the second quarter of 2009 to the second quarter of 2008, Hong Kong's GDP shrank 3.8% in the former.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong sale de la recesión|language=Spanish|date=14 Aug 2009|work=Notimex|publisher=El Universal|location=Beijing|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/619330.html|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
*August 15, 2009: {{flagicon|Portugal}} '''Portugal''' Portugal leaves recession after three consecutive quarters of negative growth having its GDP recover by 0.3% in the second quarter of 2009. According to the latest estimates by the Bank of Portugal, Portuguese GDP should fall around 3.5% in 2009, which is the worst figure for the country since 1975.<ref>{{cite news|title=Portugal sale de la recesión con un ligero aumento del PIB |language=Spanish |date=15 Aug 2009 |work=AFP |publisher=Google |location=Lisbon |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEeeLo6hkSNJv8_VbQgpTRsbSDPA |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818194419/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEeeLo6hkSNJv8_VbQgpTRsbSDPA |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=31 May 2011 |df= }} </ref>
*August 15, 2009: {{flagicon|Argentina}} '''[[Economy of Argentina|Argentina]]''' Even though official government sources state that Argentina's GDP will actually grow this year (and have only recognized a GDP shrinking in June of 0.4% and in July, of 0.3%; both compared to last year's same months), private consulting firms state that Argentine economy has actually been in recession since October 2008. According to them, Argentine GDP shrank 2.9% in the last quarter of 2008, 1.6% in the first quarter of 2009, and 0.6% in the second one.<ref>{{cite news|title=El INDEC admite por primera vez que cayó la economía|language=Spanish|date=15 Aug 2009|first=Annabella|last=Quiroga|work=Clarín|url=http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2009/08/15/elpais/p-01978829.htm|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref> It's widely known in Argentina that the official statistics office in charge of producing this information, [[INDEC]], is not very reliable for trustworthy statistical information, due to the government's mismanagement of the office.
*August 17, 2009: {{flagicon|Japan}} '''Japan''' The Japanese Government informed that after fifteen continuous months of shrinking, and after the most disastrous fall since [[World War II]] of 4% between January and March, its GDP grew 3.7% in the second quarter of 2009 in comparison with the same quarter of 2008. In annual terms, Japanese GDP grew 0.9% between April and June.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan's economy leaves recession|date=17 Aug 2009|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8204075.stm|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> Recovery was mostly contributed to recovering demand in the manufacturing sector with exports growing 6.3%. Consumer spending had only increased by 0.8% in the same period.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan emerges from recession|date=17 Aug 2009|work=Al Jazeera |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/business/2009/08/200981721746841928.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*August 24, 2009: {{flagicon|Thailand}} '''Thailand''' Thai GDP grew 2.3% in 2009's second quarter, technically leaving the recession.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thai economy emerges from recession in 2Q|date=24 Aug 2009|work=The Economic Times|location=Bangkok|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2009-08-24/news/28454785_1_thai-economy-first-quarter-recession|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===September=== *September 9, 2009: {{flagicon|Cyprus}} '''[[Economy of Cyprus|Cyprus]]''' Cyprus enters recession after 0.6% contraction in the first quarter, followed by 0.4% in the second quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title= Cyprus economy enters recession|date=8 Sep 2009|work=Trade Arabia|location=Nicosia |url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/REAL_166930.html|accessdate=7 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*September 11, 2009: {{flagicon|Brazil}} '''Brazil''' The Brazilian economy technically left the recession when GDP grew 1.9% in the second quarter of 2009 after having fallen in the first quarter of 2009 and last quarter of 2008. Growth surpassed what was expected by analysts, which was 1.6%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Economía Brasil crece 2do trim y sale de recesión|date=11 Sep 2009|first=Rodrigo Viga|last=Gaier|language=Spanish|work=Reuters América Latina|location=Rio De Janeiro|url=http://lta.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idLTASIE58A0AE20090911|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*September 11, 2009: {{flagicon|Sweden}} '''Sweden''' Sweden emerges from the recession after witnessing GDP growth of 0.2% in the second quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sweden emerges from recession|date=11 Sep 2009|work=Business & Leadership|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/leadership/item/15726-sweden-emerges-from-recession|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728032201/http://www.businessandleadership.com/leadership/item/15726-sweden-emerges-from-recession|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 July 2011|accessdate=15 May 2011}} </ref>
*September 21, 2009: {{flagicon|Macedonia}} '''[[Economy of Macedonia|Macedonia]]''' Macedonia officially enters the recession after experiencing a drop in GDP of 0.9% in the first quarter, followed by 1.4% in the second quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Macedonia enters recession|date=21 Sep 2009|first=Sinisa Jakov|last=Marusic|work=Balkan Insight |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-enters-recession|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===October=== *October 2, 2009: {{flagicon|Ireland}} '''Ireland''' The economic crisis in Ireland is considered to be the driving force behind the largest migration of Irish people to London in 20 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=London goes green as Irish recession forces biggest migration in 20 years |date=2 Oct 2009 |first=Miranda |last=Bryant |work=London Evening Standard |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23751683-london-goes-green-as-irish-recession-forces-biggest-migration-in-20-years.do |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005030104/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23751683-london-goes-green-as-irish-recession-forces-biggest-migration-in-20-years.do |archivedate=5 October 2009 |df= }}</ref>
*October 23, 2009: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The UK markets had contracted by 0.4% in the third quarter against what was expected to be a period of growth, as a result of unexpectedly poor performance by the service sector.<ref name="OCT09">{{cite news|title=Record recession for UK economy|date=23 Oct 2009|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8321970.stm|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===November=== *November 13, 2009: {{flagicon|Netherlands}} '''Netherlands''' The Netherlands officially exits the recession after experiencing 0.4% growth in the third quarter, but recovery for the Netherlands still remains fragile as the country is highly dependent on exports to maintain the recovery.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Netherlands is out of the recession |date=13 Nov 2009 |work=DutchNews |url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/11/the_netherlands_is_out_of_rece_1.php |accessdate=15 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318021341/http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/11/the_netherlands_is_out_of_rece_1.php |archivedate=18 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
*November 13, 2009: {{flagicon|Germany}} '''Germany''', {{flagicon|European Union}} '''Eurozone''' Germany's growth of 0.7% in the third quarter helped lead the Eurozone out of the recession after providing overall growth of 0.4% in the same period, with the whole European Union growing 0.2%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Germany leads Eurozone out of recession|date=13 Nov 2009|first=Francesca|last=Steele|work=Times Online|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article6915468.ece |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
*November 14, 2009: {{flagicon|Greece}} '''[[Economy of Greece|Greece]]''' The [[National Statistical Service of Greece]] states that the country had been in recession since the beginning of the year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Recession covers the whole of 2009|date=14 Nov 2009|first=Sotiris|last=Nikas|work=Ekathimerini |url=http://archive.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_economy_0_14/11/2009_112406|accessdate=5 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*November 20, 2009: {{flagicon|Mexico}} '''Mexico''' The Mexican government declared that its economy technically had left the recession when the Mexican GDP grew by 2.93% in the third quarter of 2009. Mexico had been in a severe economic crisis for over a year prior to its economic rebound. The Mexican government also approved a $244 billion budget for 2010, a slight increase from 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico's economy rebounding, recession over|date=20 Nov 2009 |work=AP|publisher=King 5|location=Mexico City|url=http://www.king5.com/news/world/70651132.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402203031/http://www.king5.com/news/world/70651132.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 April 2012|accessdate=23 May 2011}} </ref>
*November 22, 2009: {{flagicon|Venezuela}} '''[[Economy of Venezuela|Venezuela]]''' Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chavez]] states that the country has entered the recession as the economy contracted 4.5% in the third quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chavez says Venezuela in recession, by US yardstick|date=22 Nov 2009|first1=Eyanir|last1=Chinea|first2=Julio |last2=Uribarry|work=Reuters|location=Caracas|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/22/venezuela-chavez-idUSN2220285420091122|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
*November 24, 2009: {{flagicon|South Africa}} '''South Africa''' The economy grew an annualised 0.9% in the third-quarter after dropping 7.4% in the second-quarter. The recovery was attributed to government spending and the construction industry.<ref>{{cite news|title=S.Africa leaves recession with 0.9-percent growth|date=24 Nov 2009|work=Agence France-Presse|publisher=MSN News|url=http://news.ph.msn.com/business/article.aspx?cp-documentid=3718093|accessdate=13 Sep 2011}}</ref>
*November 30, 2009: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Canada begins its recovery from the recession.<ref name="canrecoverrecession"/> Economic growth is at 0.4% after 14 months of economic stagnation.<ref name="canrecoverrecession">{{cite news|title=Gross domestic product sees first gain in a year in third quarter|date=30 Nov 2009|first=David|last=Friend|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=MSN CA|location=Toronto|url=http://money.ca.msn.com/investing/news/business-news/article.aspx?cp-documentid=22757932|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref>
==2010==
===January=== The late-2000s recession has entered its second full year of existence. While many nations have managed to climb out of the recession, employment is still sparse and promises to remain so throughout 2010.
*January 10, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Canada continues its long and laborious recovery over its recession. However, people are starting to lose optimism due to the continued job losses.<ref name="winnipegsun">{{cite news|title=Expect more Canadian job losses: Flaherty|date=10 Jan 2010|first=Peter|last=Zimonjic |work=Winnipeg Sun|location=Ottawa|url=http://www.winnipegsun.com/money/2009/01/10/7978201-sun.html|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> Only Manitoba has managed to create 2000 new jobs while the rest of the nation loses approximately 105,000.<ref name="winnipegsun"/> The previous month brought in 36,000 new part-time jobs at the expense of 71,000 full-time jobs.<ref name="winnipegsun"/>
*January 10, 2010: {{flagicon|United States}} '''United States''' The US economy is expected to get worse with more job cuts.<ref name="winnipegsun"/> This will expect to have some ramification with their northern neighbor Canada.<ref name="winnipegsun"/>
*January 12, 2010: {{flagicon|Colombia}} '''Colombia''' Colombia officially leaves the recession after achieving 2% economic growth in the last quarter of 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colombian economy leaves recession: study|date=12 Jan 2010|first=Adriaan|last=Alsema|work=Colombia Reports|url=http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/economy/7634-colombian-economy-leaves-recession.html|accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref>
*January 26, 2010: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' After 6 consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth, the UK economy finally came out of recession with a GDP growth of 0.1%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Britain's out of recession: So why no cheers?|date=26 Jan 2010|first=Bruce|last=Crumley|work=Time |url=http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1956794,00.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===February=== *February 5, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Employment increased by 43,000 in January, all in part-time, pushing the unemployment rate down 0.1 percentage points to 8.3%. January marks the fourth employment gain in six months.Despite the recent increases, employment still remains 280,000 below the level of October 2008. Employment gains in January were driven by women aged 25 to 54 and youths. This was the first notable increase for youths since the start of the employment downturn in the fall of 2008. There were large increases in part-time employment in January, bringing it back to the level of six months earlier. Full-time employment was little changed in January, but has trended up over the last six months. January's increase was among private sector employees, while self-employment declined. Over the last six months, the number of private and public sector employees has been rising while self-employment has been little changed. The largest employment increases in January occurred in business, building and other support services, and retail and wholesale trade. These were partially offset by losses in professional, scientific, and technical services, as well as agriculture.<ref>{{cite web|title=Labour Force Survey|date=5 Feb 2010|publisher=Statistics Canada|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/100205/dq100205a-eng.htm|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
*February 22, 2010: {{flagicon|Republic of China}} '''Taiwan''' Taiwan's economy exits from the recession with 9.22% growth in the last quarter of 2009 after increased demand from China and other key markets in the region.<ref>{{cite news|title=Taiwan exits worst post-war recession|date=22 Feb 2010|first=Benjamin|last=Yeh|work=AFP|publisher=IndustryWeek|url=http://www.industryweek.com/articles/taiwan_exits_worst_post-war_recession_21147.aspx|accessdate=15 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100302025752/http://www.industryweek.com/articles/taiwan_exits_worst_post-war_recession_21147.aspx|archive-date=2010-03-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
*February 24, 2010: {{flagicon|European Union}} '''Eurozone''' Europe risks a double-dip recession after bad results emerged from France, Germany and Italy. The Eurozone only grew by 0.1% in the last quarter of 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Europe at risk of double-dip recession|date=24 Feb 2010|first=Ambrose|last=Evans-Pritchard|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/7301142/Europe-at-risk-of-double-dip-recession.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===March=== *March 2, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' The economy is rocketing further away from recession, increasing the chances that the Bank of Canada will lift borrowing costs more aggressively than expected later this year.<ref name="ctvnewsmarch2010">{{cite news|title=Broad recovery gains traction|date=2 Mar 2010|first1=Jeremy|last1=Torobin|first2=Tavia|last2=Grant|work=CTV News |url=http://www.ctv.ca/generic/generated/static/business/article1485998.html|accessdate=31 May 2011}} {{Dead link |date=December 2016}}</ref> Economic growth surged an annualized 5% in the fourth quarter, providing the clearest sign yet that a broad-based recovery is taking firm hold.<ref name="ctvnewsmarch2010"/> It was the fastest annualized quarterly growth since 2000, and the first solidly positive quarter since the economy entered recession in 2008 amid a global pullback brought on by the financial crisis.<ref name="ctvnewsmarch2010"/> The fourth-quarter surge was fuelled by everything from a strong housing sector and healthy consumer spending to a surprise turnaround for net trade as the country's exports grew at almost double the pace of imports, according to Statistics Canada.<ref name="ctvnewsmarch2010"/>
*March 12, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' 21,000 jobs were created in Canada as of February 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Loonie soars on jobs report|date=12 Mar 2010|work=CBC News|publisher=MSN CA|url=http://news.ca.msn.com/top-stories/cbc-article.aspx?cp-documentid=23631954|accessdate=1 May 2011}}</ref> However, employers are still not hiring people in most places including [[Stelco]] and other jobs that are in rural areas like [[Norfolk County, Ontario|Norfolk County]], [[Ontario]].
*March 24, 2010: {{flagicon|Macedonia}} '''Macedonia''' Last quarter expansion of 1.2% in 2009 officially brought Macedonia out of the recession. Overall, Macedonia's GDP contracted by 0.7% last year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Macedonia officially out of recession|date=24 Mar 2010|first=Sinisa Jakov|last=Marusic|work=Balkan Insight|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/macedonia-officially-out-of-recession|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===April=== *April 2, 2010: {{flagicon|United States}} '''United States''' 162,000 jobs were created in the United States, unemployment rate held steady at 9.7%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Signaling jobs recovery, payrolls surged in March|date=2 Apr 2010|first1=Catherine|last1=Rampell|first2=Javier C.|last2=Hernandez|work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/03/business/economy/03jobs.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*April 9, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' 17,900 new jobs were created in Canada in the previous month.<ref name="jobless82">{{cite news|title=Jobless rate remains at 8.2%|date=9 Apr 2010|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=MSN CA|url=http://news.ca.msn.com/top-stories/cbc-article.aspx?cp-documentid=23832989|accessdate=1 Jun 2011}}</ref> The trend is moving towards job creation instead of layoffs as seen in late 2008 and most of 2009.<ref name="jobless82"/> Jobs are being created in the [[private sector]] while [[public sector]] jobs are losing ground.<ref name="jobless82"/> Employment increased marginally in [[Ontario]], [[Quebec]], and [[Saskatchewan]].<ref name="jobless82"/>
*April 15, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' The union vote ratification for Stelco Lake Erie Works was confirmed with 88.5% voting in favor of the three-year deal; keeping the place open for industry.<ref name="stelcoratificationconfirmed">{{cite news|title=Stelco ratification confirmed|date=15 Apr 2010|work=Steel Market Update|url=http://www.steelmarketupdate.com/pub/blog/posts/2010/4/15/usw-ratifies-contract-with-u-s-steel|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref name="ussteeendslockoutatontarioplant">{{cite news|title=U.S. Steel ends lockout at Ontario plant|date=16 Apr 2010|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/story/2010/04/16/steelworkers-nanticoke-strike-lockout.html|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> As a result, numerous jobs in the local area were saved by this "eleventh hour" action.
===May=== *May 31, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Canadian factories hummed, consumers bought more houses, governments spent more money, prices increased and the economy posted its best quarter of growth in more than 10 years.<ref name="canbestecononomy10years"/> The Canadian economy expanded at an annualized rate of 6.1% in the first quarter, surpassing analyst expectations and marking the best growth rate since 1999.<ref name="canbestecononomy10years"/> Economists had expected annualized GDP growth of 5.9% in the last quarter, up from 5% in last year's fourth quarter.<ref name="canbestecononomy10years"/> The growth in the first quarter is the third straight quarter of economic expansion in Canada, coming on the heels of three consecutive quarters of contraction.<ref name="canbestecononomy10years"/> March growth came in at 0.6%, ahead of the 0.5% estimate.<ref name="canbestecononomy10years">[http://baystreet.money.ca.msn.com/quotedata/partners/msn/ca/the_economy.aspx Canadian economic growth best in 10 years - May 31, 2010] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529180821/http://baystreet.money.ca.msn.com/quotedata/partners/msn/ca/the_economy.aspx |date=May 29, 2010 }}</ref>
===June=== *June 9, 2010: {{flagicon|Hungary}} '''Hungary''' Hungary leaves the recession after experiencing 0.9% growth in the first quarter as a result of growing exports and effective government spending measures.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hungary exits recession in first quarter|date=9 Jun 2010|work=The Economic Times|location=Budapest|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-06-09/news/27613960_1_first-quarter-hungary-services-sector|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*June 9, 2010: {{flagicon|Finland}} '''Finland''' Finland falls back into a state of recession after GDP contracted 0.4% in Q1 2010 and 0.2% in Q4 2009. The country witnessed negative growth of 7.8% in 2009, being the worst result since 1918.<ref>{{cite news|title=Finland falls back into recession|date=9 Jun 2010|work=Al Jazeera|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/06/201069135415800303.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref> Apart from Luxembourg, Finland maintained [[Eurozone#Fiscal policies|EU fiscal policy]] by keeping debt at 44% of GDP, under the 60% limit.<ref>{{cite news|title=Finland in double-dip recession|date=9 Jun 2010|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10272574|accessdate=27 Jun 2011}}</ref>
===July=== *July 2, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Twenty thousand new jobs were added to Canada's economy.<ref name="20000newjobscanada">{{cite news|title=20000 fewer jobless people in Canada|date=2 Jul 2010|work=Canada.com|url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=3229189|accessdate=4 Jul 2010}} {{Dead link|date=May 2011}}</ref> The unemployment rate is expected to have stayed at 8.1%.<ref name="20000newjobscanada"/> Economists expect initiated home building was at an annual rate of 192,000 last month, up from 189,100 in May.<ref name="20000newjobscanada"/>
*July 23, 2010: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The [[Office for National Statistics|ONS]] released preliminary figures showing that economic growth had accelerated from 0.3% in Q1 2010 to 1.1% in Q2. This is almost double the original forecast of 0.6% growth, and the news is a welcome surprise.<ref>{{cite news|title=Preliminary Q2 GDP figures rocket|date=23 Jul 2010|first=Lee|last=Jones|work=Money Marketing |url=http://www.moneymarketing.co.uk/regulation/news/preliminary-q2-gdp-figures-rocket/1015655.article|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref> In late August, this figure was revised up to 1.2% growth as a result of greater construction output.<ref>{{cite news|title=INSTANT VIEW-UK Q2 GDP unexpectedly revised up to 1.2% qq|date=27 Aug 2010|work=London South East|location=London|url=http://www.lse.co.uk/FinanceNews.asp?ArticleCode=eoyrgeydc5tyyxz&ArticleHeadline=INSTANT_VIEWUK_Q2_GDP_unexpectedly_revised_up_to_12_qq|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref> However, large budget cuts are being put into action by the new coalition government to tackle the £163bn budget deficit that the country faces.
===August=== *August 6, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' From April to June, Canada added a massive 225,000 jobs, over half of all of the year-over-year gains since July 2009, which has nearly brought Canada’s employment to pre-recession levels.<ref name="conferenceboard">{{cite news|title=Canada’s economy takes a break|date=6 Aug 2010|first=Eric|last=Thomson|work=Conference Board of Canada|url=http://www.conferenceboard.ca/reports/cmaag/2010/cmaag082010.aspx |accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> Now that growth is beginning to normalize, employment and gross domestic product growth paused in July.<ref name="conferenceboard"/> Canada’s economy shed 9,000 jobs, pushing the employment rate up slightly to 8.0%.<ref name="conferenceboard"/> The 139,000 full-time jobs lost were largely offset by the 130,000 gained in part-time employment.<ref name="conferenceboard"/>
===September=== *September 8, 2010: {{flagicon|Egypt}} '''[[Economy of Egypt|Egypt]]''' Egypt's Minister of Finance, [[Youssef Boutros Ghali|Dr. Youssef Butros Ghali]], states that Egypt emerged from the recession as indicated by increased total revenue from sales taxes and customs revenues.<ref>{{cite news|title=Budget records: Egypt economy emerges from recession|date=8 Sep 2010|first=Sarah|last=Khan|work=Global Arab Network|location=Cairo|url=http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/201009087185/Economics/budget-records-egypt-economy-emerges-from-recession.html|accessdate=15 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008044013/http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/201009087185/Economics/budget-records-egypt-economy-emerges-from-recession.html|archive-date=2011-10-08|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
*September 10, 2010: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Statistics Canada said an additional 36,000 people got jobs in August, but the unemployment rate rose 0.1 percentage points, to 8.1%, as a larger number of people sought work.<ref name="36000newjobscanada">{{cite news|title=Jobs report suggests weakness: economists |date=10 Sep 2010 |work=CBC News Canada |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/09/10/unemployment-august.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912141740/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/09/10/unemployment-august.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 September 2010 |accessdate=2 Oct 2010 |df= }} </ref> That raised the number of unemployed by 17,800, to slightly more than 1.5 million.<ref name="36000newjobscanada"/> Excluding the bounce in education jobs, employment actually fell by about 32,000, economists at BMO Capital Markets and CIBC said.<ref name="36000newjobscanada"/>
*September 20, 2010: {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The National Bureau of Economic Research state that the US left the recession in June 2009, with managing director [[Lakshman Achuthan]] of the [[Economic Cycle Research Institute]] saying GDP recovered to 70% of the pre-recession level.<ref>{{cite news|title=Recession officially ended in June 2009|date=20 Sep 2010|first=Chris|last=Isidore|work=CNN Money|url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/09/20/news/economy/recession_over/index.htm |accessdate=26 Jun 2011}}</ref>
===October=== *October 31, 2010: {{flagicon|Belgium}} '''Belgium''' Belgium leaves the recession with 0.5% growth in the third quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Belgium exits recession in third quarter: central bank|date=31 Oct 2010|work=Expatica|url=http://www.expatica.com/be/news/belgian-news/Belgium-exits-recession-in-third-quarter_-central-bank_57710.html|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
===December=== * December 7, 2010: {{flagicon|Iceland}} '''Iceland''' Iceland officially leaves the recession with growth of 1.2% in the third quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iceland exits recession|date=7 Dec 2010|last=Inman|first=Phillip|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/dec/07/iceland-exits-recession-third-quarter|accessdate=16 Apr 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Iceland finally emerges from recession|date=7 Dec 2010|last=Murchie|first=Kay |work=Finance Markets|url=http://www.financemarkets.co.uk/2010/12/07/iceland-finally-emerges-from-recession|accessdate=16 Apr 2011}}</ref>
==2011==
===January=== *January 25, 2011 {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' It was announced the UK economy suffered a shock contraction of 0.5% in the fourth quarter of 2010, which has been widely blamed on the severe winter weather in December and austere budget cuts implemented by the coalition government increasing fears that the UK is heading for a double-dip recession. However, overall economic growth for 2010 was 1.4%.<ref>{{cite news|title=The UK economy fell by 0.5% against forecast |date=25 Jan 2011 |last=Kumar |first=Vikram |work=News Woofer |url=http://www.newswoofer.com/the-uk-economy-fell-by-0-5-against-forecast-513 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320090127/http://www.newswoofer.com/the-uk-economy-fell-by-0-5-against-forecast-513/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=12 May 2011 |df= }} </ref>
===February=== *February 9, 2011 {{flagicon|Latvia}} '''Latvia''' Latvia leaves deep recession with an annualised growth of 3.7% in the last quarter of 2010, meaning the Latvian economy only shrank by 0.2% in 2010, compared to 18% in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=UPDATE 2-Latvia Q4 growth provides further Baltic boost|date=9 Feb 2011|work=Reuters|location=Riga|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/09/latvia-economy-idUSLDE7181M420110209|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
*February 21, 2011 {{flagicon|Thailand}} '''Thailand''' Thailand's GDP rose 3.8% in the fourth quarter of 2010 after a minor recession caused by GDP contractions of 0.4% in the second quarter and 0.3% in the third quarter of 2010. The growth of the fourth quarter was attributed to a strengthening global economy, along with increasing income levels in the nation and greater liquidity by financial institutions to help the private sector. Full-year growth was recorded at 7.8%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thailand emerges from recession|date=21 Feb 2011|first=Piyarat|last=Setthasiriphaiboon|work=The Wall Street Journal|location=Bangkok|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703498804576157283489274572|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*February 23, 2011 {{flagicon|Venezuela}} '''Venezuela''' Venezuela's economy grew 0.6% in the last quarter of 2010, technically leaving the recession after six quarters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela emerges from recession with 0.6% fourth quarter growth|date=27 Feb 2011|work=Venezuelanalysis.com|location=Caracas |url=http://venezuelanalysis.com/news/6029|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref> Concern has been expressed by economists with regards to the economy improving due to instability in the private sector pressured by the socialist government,<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela central bank sees faster 2011 growth|date=27 Feb 2011|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/27/venezuela-economy-idUSN2714334920110227|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref> as José Guerra, former manager at the [[Central Bank of Venezuela]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela's economy signals recession |date=13 Feb 2009 |work=El Universal |location=Caracas |url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2009/02/13/en_eco_esp_venezuelas-economy_13A2225043.shtml |accessdate=27 Jun 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218232640/http://english.eluniversal.com/2009/02/13/en_eco_esp_venezuelas-economy_13A2225043.shtml |archivedate=2009-02-18 |df= }}</ref> stated that private investment, accounting for half of Venezuela's GDP, dropped 2.2% in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela out of recession, but doubts remain|date=23 Feb 2011|first=Fabiola|last=Sanchez|work=AP|publisher=The Palm Beach Post|location=Caracas |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/money/venezuela-out-of-recession-but-doubts-remain-1276764.html|accessdate=27 Jun 2011}} {{Dead link |date=December 2016}}</ref>
===March=== *March 30, 2011: {{flagicon|Wales}} '''[[Economy of Wales|Wales]]''' The global credit information group [[Experian]] highlighted in a report that the economic recovery for Wales is slower than the rest of the UK, stating a forecasted growth of 1.6% per year over the next decade as compared to 2.2% for the rest of the United Kingdom. Issues for Wales were attributed to low export rates, an unskilled workforce and low entrepreneurism, leading to less opportunities for growth.<ref>{{cite news|title=Experian warns of slower Welsh recovery from recession|date=30 Mar 2011|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-12898142|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
===May=== *May 5, 2011: {{flagicon|Portugal}} '''Portugal''' Portugal's Minister of Finance [[Teixeira dos Santos]] warns that the upcoming bail-out package of €78 billion is expected to shift Portugal into recession for at least 2 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Portugal faces two years of recession, warns finance minister Teixeira dos Santos|date=5 May 2011|first=Louise|last=Armitstead|work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/8495998/Portugal-faces-two-years-of-recession-warns-finance-minister-Teixeira-dos-Santos.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
* May 6, 2011: {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' The [[US Department of Labor]] stated 244,000 jobs were created in April, with 235,000 added in February and 221,000 in March, but unemployment continued to grow, reaching 9%. For unemployment to be reduced to 6%, 13 million [[private sector]] jobs must be added over 3 years, meaning annual growth of 4-5% required.<ref>{{cite news|title=Economy creates 244,000 jobs in April|date=6 May 2011|first=Peter|last=Morici|work=UPI|location=College Park|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Analysis/Outside-View/2011/05/06/Outside-View-Economy-creates-244000-jobs-in-April/UPI-28601304689218|accessdate=26 Jun 2011}}</ref>
* May 13, 2011: {{flagicon|Portugal}} '''Portugal''' Portugal slips into double-dip recession after the economy contracted by 0.7% in the first quarter of 2011, with a 0.6% contraction in the last quarter of 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eurozone's economic growth accelerates|date=13 May 2011|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-13386113|accessdate=23 May 2011}}</ref> The [[European Commission]] forecast Portugal's GDP will drop 2.2% in 2011, followed by a 1.8% drop in 2012, along with public debt to reach 101.7% of GDP in 2011 and 107.4% of GDP in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Portugal re-enters recession after government cuts spending, raises taxes|date=13 May 2011|first=Joao|last=Lima |work=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-13/portugal-re-enters-recession-after-government-cuts-spending-raises-taxes.html|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
*May 13, 2011: {{flagicon|Romania}} '''Romania''' Romania officially leaves the recession after 2 years following economic growth of an annualised 1.6% in the first quarter.<ref>{{cite news|title=Romania bids recession farewell|date=13 May 2011|first=Chris|last=Bryant|work=Financial Times|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/05/13/romania-bids-recession-farewell|accessdate=15 May 2011}}</ref>
===June=== * June 24, 2011: {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''', {{flagicon|China}} '''[[Economy of China|China]]''', {{flagicon|European Union}} '''[[Economy of the European Union|European Union]]''', {{flagicon|US}} '''United States''' As house prices remain low in the US housing market, significant foreign purchases have been made by the Canadians, Chinese and Europeans (mainly French, Spanish and Italian), seeing total spending around US$16 billion.<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. housing market receiving much international attention|date=24 Jun 2011|first=Becky|last=Harris|work=U-Pack|url=http://www.upack.com/press/article/relocation-news/us-housing-market-receiving-much-international-attention-800537654|accessdate=25 Jun 2011}}</ref> Housing prices fell 3% in the first quarter of the year, seeing housing sales increase 5.1% in March.<ref>{{cite news|title=Our Real Estate Market Sees No Progress in 2011... No Win Situation, Says RealtyPartner|date=9 Jun 2011|first=Janice|last=Nichols|work=PRWeb|publisher=Yahoo! News|location=Chicago |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/prweb/20110609/bs_prweb/prweb8554880|accessdate=25 Jun 2011}}</ref>
*June 24, 2011: {{flagicon|Scotland}} '''[[Economy of Scotland|Scotland]]''' Recovery for Scotland from the recession is stifled by the risk of stagnation from a weak rate of recovery in exports and business investments.<ref>{{cite news|title=Economic experts issue 'stagnation' warning over Scottish economy|date=24 Jun 2011|work=Daily Record |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2011/06/24/economic-experts-issue-stagnation-warning-over-scottish-economy-86908-23223740|accessdate=27 Jun 2011}}</ref>
===July=== *July 27, 2011: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' After figures showed that the 0.5% contraction in Q4 2010 was cancelled out by a 0.5% rise in Q1 2011, growth estimates from the ONS suggest that the growth in the UK is slowing down, after figures of 0.2% GDP increase was posted. Sovereign debt in the Eurozone and EU cause the stock market to crash from a FTSE-100 high of 6100 points to just above 5000.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
===September=== *September 15, 2011 {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' The [[St. Thomas Assembly]] plant was closed permanently after decades of providing employing to the region of [[St. Thomas, Ontario|St. Thomas]], [[Ontario]]; resulting in the loss of roughly 1,400 good-paying jobs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/09/16/ontario-ford-plant-closure-brings-tears |title=Ontario Ford plant closure brings tears |work=CTV |date=September 16, 2011}}</ref>
===November=== *November 1, 2011 {{flagicon|Canada}} '''Canada''' Bick's is closing down its [[Oil depot|tank farm]] in [[Norfolk County, Ontario|Delhi]], [[Ontario]] in November 2011.<ref name="bicksclosingdownindelhi">{{cite news|title=Local Bick's plants closing|date=Nov 2010|first=Monte|last=Sonnenberg|work=Simcoe Reformer|url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2777927&archive=true|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> One hundred and fifty [[full-time job]]s will be lost by this move in addition to secondary industries and retailers.<ref name="bicksclosingdownindelhi"/>
==2012==
===March=== *March 22, 2012: {{flagicon|Ireland}} '''Ireland''' Ireland returns to recession as GDP falls by 0.2% in the fourth quarter of 2011 following a fall of 1.1% in the third quarter.<ref>{{cite news | title = Ireland back in recession as global slowdown hits exports | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2012-03-22 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2012/mar/22/ireland-recession-global-slowdown-exports | accessdate = 2013-01-25}}</ref>
===April=== *April 25, 2012: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The UK economy returns to recession with a fall of 0.2% in GDP in the first quarter of 2012 following a fall of 0.3% in the last quarter of 2011.<ref>{{cite news | title = UK economy in double-dip recession | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-04-25 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17836624 | accessdate = 2013-01-01}}</ref>
===July=== *July 25, 2012: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The [[Recession shapes#W-shaped recession|double dip recession]] in the UK economy continues with a fall of 0.7% in GDP in the second quarter of 2012.<ref>{{cite news | title = UK recession deepens after 0.7% fall in GDP | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-07-25 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18977084 | accessdate = 2013-01-01}}</ref>
===August=== *August 14, 2012: {{flagicon|Hungary}} '''[[Economy of Hungary|Hungary]]''' Hungary falls back into recession as GDP falls by 0.2% in the second quarter of 2012 following a fall of 1.0% in the first quarter.<ref>{{cite news | title = Hungarian Economy Slips Into Second Recession in 4 Years | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 2012-08-14 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-14/hungarian-economy-slips-into-second-recession-in-4-years.html | accessdate = 2013-02-16}}</ref>
===October=== *October 25, 2012: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' The double dip recession in the UK economy ends with growth of 1.0% in GDP in the third quarter of 2012, with help from the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London Olympic Games]].<ref>{{cite news | title = UK economy returns to growth with help from Olympics | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-10-25 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20078231 | accessdate = 2013-01-01}}</ref>
===November=== *November 15, 2012: {{flagicon|EU}} '''Eurozone''' The [[Eurozone]] economy returns to recession with a fall of 0.1% in GDP in the third quarter of 2012 following a fall of 0.2% in the previous quarter.<ref>{{cite news | title = Eurozone back in recession | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-11-15 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20340909 | accessdate = 2013-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=GDP down by 0.1% in the euro area and up by 0.1% in the EU27 |publisher=[[Eurostat]] |date=2012-11-15 |url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-15112012-AP/EN/2-15112012-AP-EN.PDF |format=pdf |accessdate=2013-01-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121209214713/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_PUBLIC/2-15112012-AP/EN/2-15112012-AP-EN.PDF |archivedate=2012-12-09 |df= }}</ref>
===December=== *December 5, 2012: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' In his [[Autumn Statement]], [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]] [[George Osborne]] cuts the UK growth forecast for 2013 to 1.2% from the 2% forecast in the [[2012 United Kingdom budget|budget]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Autumn Statement: At-a-glance summary of key points | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-12-05 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20606382 | accessdate = 2013-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Autumn Statement: A wintry statement of reality | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2012-12-04 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20597549 | accessdate = 2013-02-22}}</ref>

==2013==

*January 25, 2013: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} '''United Kingdom''' Initial GDP figures for the fourth quarter of 2012 show the UK economy shrank by 0.3% raising fears of a triple dip recession.<ref>{{cite news | title = UK heading for triple-dip recession as GDP shrinks 0.3% in fourth quarter | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2013-01-25 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/jan/25/uk-triple-dip-recession-gdp | accessdate = 2013-01-25}}</ref>

*February 14, 2013: {{flagicon|EU}} '''European Union''' The recession in the Eurozone economy deepens with a fall of 0.6% in GDP in the fourth quarter of 2012. *February 22, 2013: {{flagicon|EU}} '''European Union''' The [[European Commission]] forecast for 2013 expects growth of 0.1% across the 27 members of the EU but a contraction of 0.3% in the Eurozone economy.<ref>{{cite news | title = Eurozone downturn and deficits to persist, Commission says | publisher = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 2013-02-22 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21544328 | accessdate = 2013-02-22}}</ref>
*February 22, 2013: {{flagicon|Bermuda}} '''[[Economy of Bermuda|Bermuda]]''' In its National Economic Report of Bermuda for 2012, the Bermudan Ministry of Finance expects GDP will decline by 0% to 1.5% in 2013 but five years of recession will end with "modest growth in 2014". {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} '''Vasanta Habba''' ({{lang-kn|ವಸಂತ ಹಬ್ಬ}}), which means ''spring festival'' in the [[Kannada]] language, is a cultural festival organised by the [[Nrityagram]] foundation in the city of [[Bangalore]], India. It is a very popular event and is considered the classical [[Woodstock]] of [[India]].<ref name="wood">{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2002-01-29/bangalore/27112291_1_yakshagana-bharat-natyam-neyveli|title=Vasanthahabba from Feb 2|work=Online Edition of The Times of India, dated 2004-01-29|publisher=The Times Internet Ltd|accessdate=2007-08-12|date=2002-01-29}}</ref> This festival, first held in the year 1990, was the brainchild of [[Protima Bedi]], the founder of [[Nrityagram]].<ref name="vh">{{cite web|url=http://thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/02/06/stories/2003020600890100.htm|work=Online Edition of The Hindu, dated 2003-02-06|title=A habba in Vasantha|author=Sonira Gulhati|accessdate=2007-08-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930182415/http://thehindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/02/06/stories/2003020600890100.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-30}}</ref> The festival is held in the premises of Nrityagram at [[Hesaraghatta]] in the outskirts of Bangalore and attracts the best musicians, dancers and cultural artists from across India.<ref name="arti">{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/archives/jan172004/metro1.asp|work=Online Edition of The Deccan Herald, dated 2004-01-17|title=A spring in their step|author=Kavita Mandana|publisher=The Printers (Mysore) Private Ltd|accessdate=2007-08-12}}</ref> Starting from an audience of about 3000 in its inaugural year, the 2003 edition saw over 40,000 people attending the event.
==Festival== The festival is one-night festival which starts in the late evening and goes on till the early morning of the next day. It is held in the amphitheatre located in the premises of Nrityagram at Hesaragahatta, which is a small village located 35 kilometres from the city of Bangalore. There is no entry fee and the seats are available on a first-come basis. Due to this fact, the seats start filling up from the afternoon itself.<ref name="vh"/> The publicity for the festival is held in a unique manner by employing folk artists and other troupes who perform on the roads of Bangalore, which publicise the event and also act as a curtain-raiser for the festival. The event is organised with the help of volunteers who belong to the colleges in the city. Many like-minded people also contribute to the event by sponsoring food stalls at the venue, organising food for the artists and also providing cars and other automobiles for ferrying musicians and artists to the venue.<ref name="vh"/> The amphitheatre can accommodate about 3,000 people and large screens are provided outside the venue for people who could not get a seat in time.
==Chronology== ===2002=== Held on 2 Feb 2002, the artists who performed included [[Aruna Sairam]] (Carnatic vocal), the Warsi brothers, [[Ateeq Hussain Khan]] ([[Qawwali]]) and Suma Sudhindra (who introduced the Tarangini veena). This event was beamed live on [[Doordarshan]] and also received good coverage on other TV channels
===2003=== Performances in this edition of Vasanta Habba included a concert on the [[Mohan Veena]] by [[Grammy Award]] winner, Pandit [[Vishwa Mohan Bhatt]], [[fusion music]] by Taufiq Querishi and [[qawwali]] by the Ateeq Hussain Khan Warsi brothers. This event was attended by over 40,000 people.
===2004=== Held on 7 Feb 2004, the artists who performed included the renowned saxophonist [[Kadri Gopalnath]] and the [[Carnatic music]] exponent, [[Bombay Jayashri]].
==Current Scenario== The event was not held in the year 2005 because India was facing the after-effects of the [[Indian Ocean tsunami]]. Habba was never held again and Nrityagram blamed it on a financial crisis. Since Nrityagram has not commented on the fate of Habba, it is assumed that the festival has been scrapped for good. Meanwhile, their dance ensemble has consistently received rave reviews and now go on frequent annual performance tours to the USA and other countries.<ref name="crunch">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2007/03/03/stories/2007030301100300.htm|title=Waiting for their spring|author=B. V. Shiva Shankar|work=Online Edition of The Hindu, dated 2007-03-03|accessdate=2007-08-13|location=Chennai, India|date=2007-03-03}}</ref>
